title: Tech stock gyrations suggest boom's end is near
text:
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. (Photo: Richard Drew, AP)
6 CONNECT 43 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE SAN FRANCISCO — I took a vacation in the Poconos last week and the stock market reverted to late 2009. Or was it early 2001?
Whichever year is more appropriate, the market’s plunge, subsequent increase in volatility and widespread price weakness among Nasdaq leaders strongly suggest we’re close to the end of a multi-year boom in tech investing.
A look at another long-term trend also argues that tech-stock prices are now roaming the border between boom and bust levels.
The report last week from Yardeni Research shows that amid the stock-price plunge and sharp snap-back of last week, one thing is still true:
Tech shares remain expensive relative to Wall Street’s expectations for the earnings growth of the companies behind them.
As of Aug. 20, the information technology sector of the S&P 500 Index was trading at 15.7 times the forward-looking, per-share estimates of the companies that comprise it.

The so-called price-to-earnings ratio of tech stocks has been drifting sideways near the 16 level for all of 2015.
It hasn’t been that high for a sustained period of time since the second half of 2009.
While not a perfect predictor of market direction, the ratio shows where investors’ appetites are on the spectrum from fearful bearishness to greedy bullishness.
Its current level shows one of two things are about to happen:
Either tech companies are going to trounce Wall Street’s earnings expectations for the remainder of this year and justify their rich valuations.
Or, the overall appetite for risk is about to drop, taking tech-stock valuations with them.
Given that five of the six largest public stock offerings of the current tech investment boom all dropped below their IPO price sooner or later, including offerings from Alibaba BABA , Twitter TWTR , Facebook FB , Groupon GRPN and Zynga ZNGA , it’s easy to understand why the fear of risk is up.
Zynga CEO Mark Pincus at the company's San Francisco headquarters on June 26, 2012. Effective Wednesday, April 8, 2015, Pincus is back as CEO of Zynga, the online game company he founded and two years ago turned over to Don Mattrick, the former head of Microsoft's Xbox division. (Photo: Paul Sakuma, AP)
It’s been 20 summers since the Netscape IPO showed that professional stock investors were willing to buy technology growth-stock offerings even when the companies behind them had yet to make a profit.
When they showed a willingness to adopt a higher level of risk, fund managers also bestowed higher valuations on profitable firms.
These companies become market leaders, sustaining long-term bull runs that carry historically-high P/E ratios.
But this bull fever doesn’t continue unabated.
As bear markets for tech shares show, including ones in 2001-2002 and in 2008, sometimes it leaves for a year or two.
And when the fever breaks, the resulting trading action is like a wild frontier where only the strong survive.
Marginal companies – ones that don’t own the No. 1 or No. 2 market share in their main business — get trampled along with their shareholders.
Given that estimates for China’s economic growth are now being cut, any investors counting on that country to generate growth in their tech portfolios will be disappointed.
Last week’s trading action looks a lot like one that’s nearing the end of a tech-investment cycle.
Like the one that began in 1995, became volatile in 2000 and collapsed in late 2001, this current cycle of rising tech valuations is six years long.
When risk and volatility go up, owning overpriced growth stocks can be a painful experience for retail investors.
There may yet be another rally this year among the strongest, most valuable tech companies such as Apple, Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Facebook.
But even if it comes it's likely to be sucking wind, running on fear and followed by many months of portfolio pain.
